column7: What is Interest and how can it be capitalized?
column8:
Interest is the additional amount of money that is paid by a borrower to a lender in exchange for using their money. It is typically calculated as a percentage of the principal amount borrowed.

For example, if you borrow $100 with a 5% annual interest rate, you would owe $5 in interest at the end of the year.

Interest can be capitalized by adding it to the principal amount of the loan, which then becomes the new amount on which interest is calculated. This means that interest is being charged on the original loan amount as well as on the interest that has already accrued. This can result in the borrower owing more money over time.
